section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background, engage children with a song, and introduce vocabulary (garbage, trash).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking, Where does garbage go?
Read for enjoyment, pointing out the different shapes in the book.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize, name, and describe common two-dimensional shapes—circle, square, rectangle, triangle—using words related to number of sides, length of sides, and number of points or angles.
Follow classroom rules and routines.
Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Understand and use varied types of words.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Show children three different shapes that they will identify and name.
Have children identify shapes and their attributes in a matching activity.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we care for our world?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What book did you choose? What is the book about?
Pretend to drive a garbage truck. Where are you going?
Can you make a circle shape with your fingers? What makes it a circle?
Can you write about what happens to garbage after we throw it away?
What shapes do you see in your creation?
Which letters do you see two times in the word garbage?
What are you building? Can you make a square shape with blocks?

TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder follow rules and routine and introduce vocabulary (community).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Follow That Garbage!.
Read closely to reinforce following rules and routines and to recognize shapes.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize, name, and describe common two-dimensional shapes—circle, square, rectangle, triangle—using words related to number of sides, length of sides, and number of points or angles.
Follow classroom rules and routines.
Use technology to find information; Use digital tools and resources safely; Show understanding of common technology and how it affects how people live.
Use different art materials for exploration and for sensory experience.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Ask children to follow a rule for creating an image with Pattern Blocks.
Instruct children to include a set number of a specific shape in their work.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we care for our world?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What community is in that book?
Pretend to be following a garbage truck’s routine.
Can you show me some circles and squares in the room?
What is your community like? Can you write about it?
Draw a shape. What shape did you make?
What sound do you hear at the beginning of the name of your favorite shape?
Why did you make that shape with those blocks?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Follow That Garbage!: A Journey to the Landfill by Bridget Heos, illustrated by Alex Westgate. Copyright © 2017 by Amicus. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with The Creative Company dba Amicus Publishing. Clifford the Big Red DogTM illustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about solid shapes, have children identify shapes, and introduce vocabulary (landfill, solid shape).
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking the guiding question, What happens to the garbage after it gets picked up?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension and further exploration of shapes in the book.
Check understanding. Differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Begin to recognize common three-dimensional shapes, describing them as balls, boxes, cans, and cones.
Follow classroom rules and routines.
Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Understand and use varied types of words.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Ask children to identify and name objects that are solid shapes.
Have children identify shapes and their attributes in a matching activity.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we care for our world?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you show me some shapes in that book?
Pretend to be a bouncy ball. What shape are you?
Try and put two triangles together to make another shape.
Write about a garbage truck driver’s job.
Can you draw a picture that has circles and squares in it?
Can you find three things in the room that start with the same beginning sound as ball?
What can you build with box-shaped blocks?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Follow That Garbage!: A Journey to the Landfill by Bridget Heos, illustrated by Alex Westgate. Copyright © 2017 by Amicus. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with The Creative Company dba Amicus Publishing. Photo © Nenov Brothers Images/Shutterstock.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_materials-caption.tg_materials-caption_book-title-Ital: Big Chart of Big Ideas: You Can Help

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Science:Earth and Space Science; Life Science

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to discuss protecting the Earth and introduce vocabulary (Earth, recycle).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts Follow That Garbage! and You Can Help .
Read interactively and connect to geometry by pointing out different shapes.
Offer an extended play activity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Begin to recognize common three-dimensional shapes, describing them as balls, boxes, cans, and cones.
Follow classroom rules and routines.
Show understanding and the importance of taking care of the planet.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the relationship between plants and animals and their environments.
Use technology to find information; Use digital tools and resources safely; Show understanding of common technology and how it affects how people live.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Science:Earth and Space Science; Life Science

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Review solid shape images with children.
Have children find examples of solid shapes in the classroom and describe them.
Discuss recycling items.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we care for our world?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What was your favorite part of that book?
What sounds would you make if you were being a garbage truck? What is the best part of being a garbage truck?
This shape is bigger than this one. Are they both triangles?
Write about the Earth. What is special about it?
Draw a picture with two of your favorite shapes.
Draw a letter. Can you think of something in the room that starts with that letter?
What solid shapes are you building with?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Follow That Garbage!: A Journey to the Landfill by Bridget Heos, illustrated by Alex Westgate. Copyright © 2017 by Amicus. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with The Creative Company dba Amicus Publishing. Photo © Aleksey Sagitov/Shutterstock.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Photo © New Africa/Shutterstock.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Science:Earth and Space Science; Life Science

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to connect the book to language and to play a guessing game with children about shapes.
Start Story Time by revisiting the book and asking, How can we help make less garbage?
Read and retell the story interactively for physical engagement and a focus on shapes.
Check understanding. Differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize, name, and describe common two-dimensional shapes—circle, square, rectangle, triangle—using words related to number of sides, length of sides, and number of points or angles; Begin to recognize common three-dimensional shapes, describing them as balls, boxes, cans, and cones.
Follow classroom rules and routines.
Use increasingly complex word forms.
Show understanding and the importance of taking care of the planet.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the relationship between plants and animals and their environments.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: What can we do to protect the Earth?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we care for our world?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What kind of book do you imagine you want to read next?
What is something you could do with a cardboard box? Can you think of anything else?
What shape is this? What shape will you create if you combine shapes?
Write a story about caring for the Earth.
Can you create a picture of a garbage truck? What shapes are in it?
What sounds do you hear in the word trash? Write all the letters that you hear.
Build a place where people can recycle their old things.

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Follow That Garbage!: A Journey to the Landfill by Bridget Heos, illustrated by Alex Westgate. Copyright © 2017 by Amicus. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with The Creative Company dba Amicus Publishing.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Name common shapes.
Follow classroom rules and routines with occasional reminders from teacher.
Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Name common shapes.
Follow classroom rules and routines with occasional reminders from teacher.
Use technology to access appropriate information.
Practice safe behavior while using digital tools and resources.
Use a variety of art materials and activities for sensory experience and exploration.
Name common shapes.
Follow classroom rules and routines with occasional reminders from teacher.
Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Name common shapes.
Follow classroom rules and routines with occasional reminders from teacher.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss the relationship of organisms to their environment.
Demonstrate the importance of caring for our environment and our planet.
Use technology to access appropriate information.
Practice safe behavior while using digital tools and resources.
Name common shapes.
Follow classroom rules and routines with occasional reminders from the teacher.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss the relationship of organisms to their environment.
Demonstrate the importance of caring for our environment and our planet.
Use single words and simple phrases to communicate meaning in social situations.
